author: Sophie Evans
title: "I'm so scared": Terrified single mum breaks down in tears as she prepares for cancer surgery - Mirror Online
text:
Charlie shares an insight into her tongue cancer treatment Share this video Watch Next Charlie initially thought she would die after being diagnosed with tongue cancer (Photo: Handout) 
"It was so painful," she told Mirror Online, adding that three different dentists initially diagnosed her lesion as being related to a wisdom tooth. 
"They said I had a wisdom tooth that was growing through and it was causing me to have an inflammation in my gum and on my tongue," she said. 
She added that she was mistakenly diagnosed - and given antibiotics to take - for around four to five months before she decided to go to hospital. 
"The pain was growing," she said. 
Charlie went to the minor injuries unit, where she was referred to an orthodontist, who recognised something else was wrong with her mouth. 
He took a biopsy and ultimately discovered she had cancer. Her devoted dad, Haydn, says: "If I could take the operation on myself, I would, of course" (Photo: Charlie Rees) 
"I desperately want, with all of my heart, for people to know that they need a biopsy they have a similar problem and it doesn’t go away," Charlie said. 
"I want dentists to know that too. I was so upset that this had happened." 
She added that she still remembers how "frightened" she was to hear her diagnosis. 
“I had a sort of 'out of body' experience," she said. 
"You know that everything is about to change.” 
Last November, Charlie underwent 12-hour surgery. 
Forty per cent of her tongue was removed and reconstructed, using a muscle and blood supply from her forearm, and skin grafts from her stomach. 
Fortunately, the operation went well, In another video, taken shortly after the procedure, she says groggily: "I can talk, I really can!" Ahead of her surgery, Charlie bravely vowed: "You'll never shut me up" (Photo: Handout) 
The thought of not being able to talk and communicate had terrified the mum, whose career had been in the world of communication. 
She had built her identity on using her voice through speech and singing. 
Charlie, who lives in Newbury, Berkshire, with her son, Tyler, told Mirror Online she had to teach herself how to speak properly again after her surgery. 
"The operation went well, but they didn't find my glands clear of cancer," she said, describing how around four of her 35-40 glands were infected. 
Charlie was put on a feeding tube at Reading's Royal Berkshire Hospital so she didn't "have to negotiate" food going through her mouth. 
"The level of care has been something else," she said. The mum-of-one now faces an anxious wait to find out if her treatment has been successful (Photo: Handout) 
She was also forced to undergo a gruelling course of chemotherapy and radiotherapy in a bid to get rid of her cancer. 
While she was in hospital, Charlie said her son was cared for by her parents, who flew over from their home in France to support them. 
"Tyler and I are a unit," she said. "He has never met his dad. He’s been on the journey with me and is coping really, really well. 
"His school have been amazing as well." 
Recently, Charlie, who works as the head of creative for a local business, finally reached the end of her course of treatment. 
She now faces an anxious wait to find out if it has been successful. Read More Heartbreaking before and after videos show 12-year-old girl left paralysed by mystery illness 
The mum continues to receive support from Macmillan , a leading UK charity which has followed her journey since her diagnosis. 
"Macmillan were there right from the start," she said. "They really carry you through it. They embrace all of your family as well.” 
She also continues to upload videos of her experience with tongue cancer on YouTube in a bid to raise awareness of the disease. 
Charlie has dedicated Facebook , Twitter , Instagram and JustGiving pages to highlight the importance of early diagnosis of mouth cancer. 
Macmillan Cancer Support provides a range of services to people affected by cancer including a telephone support line, website with information and advice, financial support and peer-to-peer support through an online community. 
For more information visit macmillan.org.uk or call 0808 808 00 00. Like us on Facebook
